prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for taking my 3yo out to do something fun whilst my partner is at work?
I will try and keep this short . 

Almost every weekend when I say lets take our kid out to the play centre or a farm ect I get one of maybe 3  excuses every time without fail . Either "I dont want to go out / I just wanna sit and play on the computer. " " ive been at work im tired I don't wanna go out / drive " or " I don't wanna spend the money on x, y ,z" ( we have money so its not like thats a real problem )   

Today a friend asked me if i wanted to go with her with the kids to the farm near us tomorrow and I said yes . I figured since we hadn't taken little one anywhere fun for a few weeks it would be nice . 

So I mentioned it to my partner and he goes off on one about how its not fair as he is at work and he would like to go blah blah . I said so I cant take her anywhere when you're at work ? Pointed out that I asked to go not a week or two earlier and was told no its too expencive and  I dont want to go out I'm tired. ( its £7 each ). 

So now he wants me to cancle with my friend so he can go another day . I said we can go whenever you want . But apparently thats not an option either . 

Its a childrens petting zoo ffs its not like im going to see a movie wothout him. 
"""

I think the author is in the wrong but curious what you think.
Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's try to figure out whether the author is in the wrong here. So, the situation is that the author, who is a parent, wanted to take their 3-year-old child out to a fun place like a play center or a farm. The partner often refuses with excuses about not wanting to go out, being tired, or not wanting to spend money, even though they have the financial means. The author then decided to go with a friend to a farm when the partner was at work. Now the partner is upset and wants to cancel the plans so he can go another day.

First, I need to consider both perspectives. The author's actions seem to come from a place of wanting to give the child a fun experience. The partner, on the other hand, might feel left out or not involved in the decision. But the key points here are the repeated refusals from the partner in the past. The author tried multiple times to go out, but the partner consistently gave excuses. This pattern suggests that the partner isn't prioritizing family outings or spending time with the child, even when they can afford it. 

The author's decision to go without the partner might be seen as a way to fulfill the child's need for stimulation and activity. The cost is only £7 each, which isn't a big sum if they have the money. The partner's reaction seems to be more about feeling left out rather than a valid concern. The author also offered to go another day with the partner, which shows willingness to compromise. 

But is the author wrong for taking the child out without the partner's agreement? In many relationships, both parents should agree on major plans, especially involving the child. However, if the partner has been consistently uncooperative, the author might feel justified in making the decision to prioritize the child's well-being. The key here is whether taking the child out when the partner is at work is a breach of trust or shared responsibility. 

On one hand, the author is acting in the child's best interest. On the other, without discussing it thoroughly and getting the partner's input, it could lead to resentment. But given the partner's past behavior, the author might have felt that this was a necessary step to provide the child with a positive experience. 

I think the main issue is the communication and the pattern of the partner's refusals. The author tried multiple times and faced excuses, so acting independently in this case might not be wrong. The partner's reaction seems more about feeling excluded than a legitimate issue with the outing itself. Therefore, the author might not be in the wrong here. So the answer would be B (No).
